title: Wednesday, 10th May, 2017
bodyHTML:

As used in All The President's Men, that page reminds.

BE11:04am

Woodward: They said Hunt hadn't worked there for three months. Then a PR guy said this weird thing to me. He said, "I am convinced that neither Mr. Colson nor anyone else at the White House had any knowledge of, or participation in, this deplorable incident at the Democratic National Committee."
Simons: Isn't that what you expect them to say?
Woodward: Absolutely.
Simons: So?
Woodward: I never asked about Watergate. I simply asked what were Hunt's duties at the White House.

BE11:04am

Not that it's a new parallel to draw.

PM11:05am

BE11:05am

BE11:06am

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Bull market ploughs on

PM11:06am

Grinds on

BE11:06am

Calmly. and the sellside is getting irritated with us getting irritated about the Vix.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Let them

BE11:07am

Here's Birinyi Associates, no less.

BE11:07am

Journalists, perhaps more than market participants, have discovered the VIX or as they often term it, the fear index. It is allegedly a critical indicator and closely watched but we do not even have it on our screen. Perhaps our attitude stems from the graph at top right. In 2009, it was consistently negative.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

"discovered" ........... I mean, if we're being patronised, at least do it accurately. We've been Vixing on these pages for more than a decade.

BE11:08am

If we take a longer perspective it somewhat coincides with corrections but even here it is a coincident and lagging indicator and we find that in rising markets it provides little insight. Thus, the fact that it is stale or at low levels is somewhat in line with our view of a generally rising market where we have a 2,450 objective by the end of the second quarter.

PM11:08am

Also, please, prices were generally going up for three quarters of 2009 -- the last three quarters

11:08 am
BE11:08am

The more intriguing element is the heavy volume. We wonder – and without concrete evidence - if it is not individuals buying while institutions are willing to sell aggressively reflecting their (the institutional view) that the market will continue to be a yin-yang affair with no discernible negative events forthcoming that would led to a downdraft in prices.

BE11:08am

Let me get the chart there,

BE11:09am

BE11:10am

Hm. I'd note the "institutional selling, retail buying" thing rather ignores the fact that the retail-institutional balance thing is seen through a very US lens.

BE11:11am

Name me another market where retail could be a counterweight to institutional selling? Yet the trends talked about are not exclusively US.

11:11 am

BE11:11am

BE11:11am

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 162.50, down 20 (-10.96%), High: 168.00, Low: 151.10, Volume: 9.82m

Review of mobile strategy to create alternative less capital intensive offering

hehehe

11:16 am

Unless you're cheap or you've something else to attach.

BE11:16am

Which is why TalkTalk is in such a bind now. Broadband all costs the same and they have nothing else to sell.

Here's USwitch this morning.

BE11:17am

hmm

BE11:18am

Few, I'd imagine.

11:18 am

11:18 am

I mean, I guess the whole "simplify" thing under Dunstone might reestablish some kind of edge, but I've yet to see either how or why.

Let me stop waffling and get some sellside.

PM11:19am

Ah, we like your waffle

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Have Goldman's waffle instead.

BE11:19am

TALK has reported weaker-than-expected FY17 results and announced a 50% dividend cut for FY18 as part of a new strategy to return to growth. Specifically, TALK is now focusing on growth ahead of cash generation/profitability. New guidance for FY18 EBITDA is c.11% below consensus, driven by higher marketing/SAC. Overall, we view this as negative for the UK fixed market (including BT), which has enjoyed price inflation in recent years.

BE11:20am

4Q17 KPIs: On-net broadband net adds were +22k in 4Q17 (vs -42k in 3Q17); within this mix overall TALK has disclosed it lost 178k retail subscribers during the year. In terms of RGUs, TALK added +45k mobile (vs 3Q17 +46k), +73k fibre (vs 3Q17 +40k) but continued to lose TV customers -14k (vs 3Q17 -31k). Churn
improved further to 1.4% (vs 1.6% in 3Q16). On-net ARPU was -1.3% lower yoy at £28.16.

We are Neutral-rated on TalkTalk, last close £1.83. Our 12-month ROIC-based price target is £1.90. Our price target includes a 15% weighting for an M&A-based valuation, based on 9.0x 2018E EV/EBITDA, reflecting previous transactions in the space. Key up/downside risks include UK market competition, cash usage, potential M&A and cost-cutting execution (existing cost-cutting targets remain largely in Talk’s control and are key for FY17 to show a material uplift in profitability).

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Macquarie ....

BE11:21am

TalkTalk has cleared the deck and dramatically rebased expectations. Unhelpful in the short term but likely to be more deliverable and constructive in the mid­term. The recent management changes allow for a new direction and different level of expectation. Looking through the Rocky and Horror elements from today, the show going forward should be more sensitive and rewarding.

BE11:21am

Barclays .....

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Greater marketing spend, higher net adds, higher Fibre additions lead to EBITDA of £286m for FY18E, a 19% reduction vs our previous forecast. At the EPS level the impact is ca30% for the coming periods. We also cut our DPS to 7.5p/share, leaving FY18E net debt broadly unchanged.

BE11:22am

The impact of rebased forecasts is to reduce our price target materially. We estimate at 184p that TalkTalk is trading on 22x March 2018E P/E, 8.5x EV/EBITDA and offers a 4.2%/6.6% dividend yield. We re-iterate our OW rating, as we see upside potential to our new DCF-based price target on the expectation of weakness in the shares this morning.

BE11:22am

Jefferies .......

11:22 am
BE11:22am

With Charles Dunstone now taking a more active role as Executive Chairman and Tristia Harrison now in place as CEO, TALK is reframing its strategic objectives. Emphasis now is on simplicity, driving retail BB growth and focusing investments on this core activity. Hence mobile strategy is now under review, with the company stating that prior plans for mobile-related infrastructure investment have been terminated. The exact shape of TALK's mobile ambitions is likely to depend on negotiations with wholesale partner O2, and appear to have not yet been finalised. However, the company is likely to reiterate its commitment to investing in backhaul, dark fibre and FTTP, activities that support retail BB. Previously TALK has suggested that there is third-party funding to support off balance sheet fibre investments.

BE11:22am

The dividend cut was deeper than expected. Final DPS this year cut to 5.00p (JEFe was 10.58p, in line with last year's final) and FY17/18 guidance for full-year DPS is 7.50p (JEFe 12.0p, FY17 10.29p, FY16 15.87p). A deeper DPS cut is welcome, reflecting the reality of TALK's current operating momentum and the priority of deleveraging. TALK's belief that the new simplified strategy (avoiding capital-intensive distractions like mobile) can accelerate FCF growth will instil hopes of a return to DPS in the medium term.

11:26 am

Hey, did you read Campling on Just Eat

11:26 am

11:27 am
BE11:27am

This is apropos of the CMA looking at Hungryhouse?

PM11:27am

First, his stuff on the competition probe

PM11:27am

Just Eat’s £200M acquisition of Hungry House faces an in-depth Phase 2 investigation by the U.K. regulator CMA (Competition and Market Authority) based on the fact that the two are close competitors because of similar services and broad geographical coverage and a merger could lead to worse terms for its restaurant clients. The CMA investigation has been ongoing but there has been no hint previously, to our knowledge, that a Phase 2 was likely. Hungry House was owned by Delivery Hero which is, in turn, majority owned by Rocket Internet (of which we have long held a Sell rating and retain a very negative view). At the time of the deal announcement in December the price for Hungry House was set at a not insignificant valuation of up to c.10x annual revenues (depending on revenue earn outs). In the UK Just Eat works with 28K restaurants and Hungry House just under 10K. At the time of the announcement Just Eat stated that the combination of the two businesses would generate economic benefits of scale, with high operating leverage driving material synergies. A CMA Phase 2 investigation does prolong the acquisition process at a time management for Just Eat who led the deal is no longer at the company. Which reminds us, there has been what we consider to be a surprising development of the same this week.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

And now the management revolving door...

PM11:28am

First we note the official RNS from Just Eat on the 10th February. "The Board of Just Eat plc (LSE: JE.) announces that, due to urgent family matters, David Buttress has informed it of his intention to step down from his role as Chief Executive Officer (at the end of the first quarter)." Then Chairman John Hughes (who has since had to take medical leave) stated "The Board would like to thank David for his outstanding contribution and respects his imminent need to focus on other important matters".

(The bold is our emphasis to be clear). So the then CEO Buttress officially leaves Just Eat on 31st March 2017. Given the “urgent family matters” we were somewhat surprised this week to learn of an announcement, just 38 days later, that Buttress is joining a VC firm, 83 North.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 196.42, down 4.38 (-2.18%), High: 201.70, Low: 196.00, Volume: 12.70m

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Revenues fell -6% to £507m driven by the decline in advertising. At its FY16 results the group indicated that 4m to April would be down -6%. May has performed broadly in line with this while June will be down 15-20% against the Euro 2016 comparative. This gives a decline of 8-9% in H1, consistent with NSe -8%. We expect a flat H2 against the softer comparative (1H16 flat, 2H16 -5%) before a return to growth (NSe +3%) in 2018 bolstered by the World Cup. Online, Pay & Interactive grew +22% in Q1.

BE11:44am

● ITV Studios. Revenues rose +7% to £343m, including FX benefit. ITVS has a strong pipeline of new and returning series and has now secured over 75% of FY17 revenues.
● Retransmission fees. The Digital Economy Bill, including the repeal of s73, has received Royal Assent and is set to become law after the election. We remain sceptical that retransmission fees will be a material boost to ITV.
● Forecasts. We retain our PBT/EPS forecasts for £805m/16.1p for 2017, rising to £860m/17.2p for 2018; consensus is 16.1p and 16.9p, respectively.

BE11:45am

ITV^ (ITV, Buy, 201p) – Q1 update. ITV has published a trading statement ahead of its AGM later today. This morning’s release which covers the three months to end March, indicates a 3% YoY revenue decline overall (in line with expectations). Broadcast & Online revenues (SCF 73% of FY17F total) fell by 6% YoY with NAR (net advertising revenue) 9% lower (previous guidance -6.0% during the first four months of the year) reflecting previously flagged caution amongst UK advertisers (although non-spot advertising revenues showed good growth). In contrast Online, Pay and Interactive revenues moved ahead by 22% YoY- driven by strong demand for online advertising. The ITV Studios (content) business (SCF 27% of FY17F revenue) posted a 7% YoY revenue increase (flat on a constant currency basis) with a strong performance flagged in the US market. Net debt at 31 March stood at £627m versus £637m at the end of December 16 and our FY17F forecast of £683m (0.8x EBITDA).

Turning to operating KPI’s, positive progress was achieved across all metrics with Q1 SOV (share of voice) and SOCI (share of commercial impacts) standing at 21.7% and 34.7% respectively across the ITV family of channels – an encouraging out-turn versus 21.2% and 34.4% at the same point last year and 21.4% and 34.4% during FY16A as a whole.

Outlook comments indicate that management expects NAR to decline by 8%-9% during H1 with declines of 8% and 15%-20% in May and June (YoY comps vs. Euro 16 Championships) following on from a 5% increase recorded in April. The Studios business has a solid pipeline of new and returning shows and despite a phasing headwind in H1, it has already secured 75% of management’s expectations on full year revenue. Finally, there is also confirmation in this morning’s release that the
amendment to the Digital Economy Bill required to allow negotiations to begin with other broadcasters (exc. Sky) on re-transmission fees will be enacted “without delay” – potentially boosting group revenues over the medium term. Overall the group’s performance and the shape of the UK advertising market are characterised as “very much” as anticipated and in it is described as on track to deliver against full year guidance

We are pleased by the trading operating performance and outlook comments contained within this morning’s update which look consistent with our assumptions for the full year. We also remain positive on the group’s medium term attractions. These include: (a) its unrivalled ability to deliver a mass market commercial audience to advertisers via what is (in contrast to many digital platforms) a trusted and well understood medium; (b) the scale and commercial value of its content portfolio, and; (c) the prospect of solid EPS growth, a very attractive income progression (SCF three year aggregate DPS growth 39% excluding further “specials”) and strong cash generation (providing fuel for acquisitions, dividend growth special payments, and de-leveraging an already under-geared balance sheet). We continue to view the group’s stock valuation (FY17F and FY18F P/E and DY ratios of 12.3x 4.3% and 11.3x 4.7% respectively) as very modest. We also believe its strategic attractions in an industry consolidating around content could lead to an external approach – with the imminent departure of its CEO potentially increasing its vulnerability. We retain our Buy recommendation.

More encouragingly, full year guidance is unchanged, Studios still expects to deliver good organic growth for the full year which is a relief, and assent for the Digital Economy Bill brings forward the potential for a boost from retransmission fees. Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 620.64, up 24.14 (+4.05%), High: 624.50, Low: 602.00, Volume: 4.06m
11:49 am
BE11:49am

PM11:50am

BE11:50am

HTB still acting the subsidy that's allowing the builders to dripfeed new house supply into the market to a captive pool of buyers.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Thereby gradually degrading the nation's housing stock with flats made of 40% recycled cardboard.

BE11:51am

Canaccord can sum up where we are here.

BE11:51am

The solid trading update points to continued good trading with FY2017 PBT expected to be at the top end of expectations. Numbers should be boosted by a strong completions outcome with gross margins close to the 20% target. Net cash is also better than expected at £600m, which supports the dividend commitment. Trading conditions looks to be very good with sales rates at good levels and pricing robust. It would appear that trading in London has not seen any material change to what the group has reported recently and the general election does not appear to be having any noticeable negative effects. The absence of any comment on leaseholds would also suggest that the group has no material issue here. Overall, this is another solid update from a housebuilder. The group looks well positioned to deliver strong results for the current financial year with momentum looking good. There remains the potential for higher operating margins over the medium term. In the near term, the shares have had a strong +28% YTD increase with valuation at 1.8 times 2017E P/NAV, which is a c.10% discount to the sector average - supported by the solid update.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Update summary

Solid trading update guides to FY2017 being at the top end of analysts' expectations (current range £675m to £733m), which is c.+3-4% above our £706m estimate.
Net private sales rate for the period was 0.80, versus 0.78 for the previous year.
Completions are higher than we expected at 16,650 and 17,350 including JVs.
Total forward sales at record levels at £3.2bn (+12.7%).
The group is still seeing good opportunities in the land market with around 17,000 plots purchased in the current financial year.
Net cash now expected to be around £600m, which is materially higher than we expected - this seems to be due to strong trading, timing of land payments and a c.£20m of share equity asset sales.
Outlook comments point to the group remaining well on track to achieve its 25% ROCE target and FY2017 gross margins of 20%. Management mentioned the potential to improve margins over the medium term.

BE11:52am

Shares are up by +28% year to date, having enjoyed a strong re-rating along with the sector. They reside on a 2017E P/NAV multiple of c.1.8 times versus the sector average of c.2.0 times and on a dividend yield of c.+7% for FY2018E versus a sector average of c.6%.

PM11:52am

Yielding 7%??

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Yep. And a line from Jefferies, Anthony Codling.

BE11:52am

Our confidence in Barratt’s performance has been rewarded as it reports today that profits will be at the top end of the City’s expectations. We had the highest profit estimates across the city and it looks to us very likely that Barratt will meet our high expectations and deliver profits in the region of £733m. Our view of a two speed housing market continues to be validated: whilst the second hand market continues to face headwinds, Barratt will deliver its highest number of home sales in nine years. We are pleased to see that Barratt has a clean bill of health with respect to leasehold issues that have hampered others and that the swiftly called general election is not having any noticeable impact on current trading. For Barratt it is full steam ahead.

PM11:53am

PM11:53am

House price stagnation

11:53 am
PM11:53am

This par caught my eye

PM11:54am

It’s not the first time buyers whoare struggling The assumption is always, in our view, that the struggling buyer has to be the first timer who cannot save up a sufficient deposit but we do not believe this is the point of greatest stress. We see the market’s pinch-point being amongst those who were first time buyers 5-7 years ago (note this would not yet include early users of help-to-buy–this is likely to present a whole, new set of issues). We see these buyers as having failed to build enough equity havingused very long mortgages (often 40 years) and having seen prices rise by 27% in 5 years while wages have risen by just 9%.

Important point, that

BE11:59am

BE11:59am

Detailed analysis shows NEXT has, unlike its peers, been actively managing its portfolio over the last 10 years. In our view this is over-looked by investors pre-occupied by short-term trading. NEXT’s estate is well-invested, and in our view margins appear sustainable, even if Retail LFLs continue to fall. Post FY18, profits should stabilise even if consumer demand remains weak, with some self-help. In our view, valuation doesn’t reflect NEXT’s qualities as a well-invested business with strong & sustainable cash flows. BUY (from Hold).

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Structural challenges have not gone away: e.g. managing the online channel shift and increased competition from pure plays & roll-outs. Demand remains weak with macros uncertain. However, detailed analysis shows that NEXT is relatively better positioned than peers.
NEXT proactively manages its estate: 53% of space didn’t exist 10 years ago, with 67% of sites new / extended. New space contributes 40% more than Retail’s average. NEXT’s portfolio reflects an active strategy: since FY07, c. 20 stores p.a. have closed and 53% of lease commitments expire by FY22, giving it the operational flexibility to adapt its estate which others lack.
Portfolio is well-invested: Over the last 10 years, on a £Sq Ft basis, spend is comparable with Primark (AB Foods: Buy). NEXT has focussed spend on new stores. M&S and Debenhams (both Sells) have focussed on refurbishments.
Current margins appear sustainable, even if Retail LFLs continue to fall: Our analysis suggests -4% Retail LFL for the next 9 years hits PBT by c. 8%. For M&S & Debenhams, the impact could be more severe (25% 66% respectively).
Profits should now start to stabilise: Post Q1’s update, we cut PBT forecasts by 3-4%. Crucially, we think profits stabilise & self-help remains available (e.g. markdown & availability). A return to buybacks would facilitate EPS growth.
Valuation (11x CY18e PE) reflects short-term trading concerns rather than NEXT’s qualities of strong cash generation (8.6% FCF yield), its well-invested estate and active management of its business in a changing environment. We lift our TP to 4750p, valuing NEXT on a 10% sector discount.
